abstractText: . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . We explore an interior solution of a physically symmetric vierbein with two unknown functions in conformal teleparallel gravity. The field equations can be described in a closed system for a particular form of the metric potentials and an appropriate anisotropic function. As a result, we find a new set of configurations consistent with observed pulsars. In particular, the boundary conditions for the interior spacetime are used for the Schwarzschild spacetime to constrain the conformal field with a unit value through the surface of a compact object. Furthermore, we apply the present model to the pulsar 4U 1608−52 with an approximate radius R = 9.52 ± 0.15 km and mass M = 1.74 ± 0.14 M . To analyze the stability, we also study the causality conditions and the adiabatic index by assuming the Tolman–Oppenheimer–Volkoff equation, an adiabatic index, and the static state. Moreover, the consistency of the model under consideration with other pulsars is investigated. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .

Subject Index E03, E30, E33
1. Introduction The exploration of gravity theories with conformal invariance [1–3] is a very important issue. This is because conformally invariant theories are predicted to be renormalizable and thus are a conceivable model of quantum gravity and a conceivable way to reach the issues of dark energy and dark matter [4]. It is an important defect that, in such a formulation, the Lagrangian includes higher-derivative expressions, yielding a fourth-order theory with the Gauss– Ostrogradsky ghost. However, under specific situations, the ghost will vanish and the theories are expected to be consistent [5,6].
Another method to overcome the problem of ghosts is to modify gravitational theories and consider the construction of torsional gravity, in which, instead of Riemannian geometry, teleparallelism is used [7]. In the teleparallel spacetime, the connection is written based on the teleparallel constraints in which the curvature vanishes. In this regard, two different classes exist.
The first class is known as symmetric teleparallel gravity theories constructed using symmetric teleparallel geometry. In this geometry, the connection is symmetric where the torsion is zero. Consequently, the geometry is prescribed by the spacetime non-metricity. This geometry was used first in Ref. [8] to construct the symmetric teleparallel equivalent of general relativity (STEGR). Further, the geometry of STEGR was extended to different modified structures [9–13].

In the second class, the connection is completely fixed by extra constraints of the metric compatibility. Thus, this geometry is depicted by the spacetime torsion, which allows the construction of completely torsional gravitational theories. A specific model of this class is the so-called ‘‘teleparallel equivalent of general relativity (TEGR)’’, which is completely equivalent to general relativity [14,15]. This theory, TEGR, was first used by Einstein in an attempt to unify electromagnetic and gravitational fields [16,17]. Moreover, TEGR theory was used as an alternative construction of Einstein’s GR in Refs. [18–25]. The TEGR theory was also employed in the frame of a metric-affine gravitational theory [26,27]. Furthermore, an alternative TEGR theory has been constructed, namely, f(T) gravity [28–45], which has become a familiar theory to discuss cosmic accelerated expansion and investigate gravitational waves [46–50]. Moreover, a non-metricity conformal symmetric teleparallel gravity has been studied in Ref. [51]. In addition, new anisotropic star solutions in mimetic gravity by imposing the Tolman–Finch–Skea metric have been discussed in Ref. [52].
In this work, we concentrate on TEGR constructed in Refs. [53,54]. There are many advantages for using the TEGR theory. For instance, the energy, momentum, and angular momentum can be defined in a consistent manner [55–57]. Also, in the extended TEGR theory, the conformal invariance should be taken into account. The main feature of its physical properties is that it is scale invariant; therefore, conformal invariance can be regarded as an extension of this invariance. The conformal term will have a coordinate dependence. We here explain the meaning of a conformal transformation by considering the spacetime (M, gab), with M being a smooth D-dimensional manifold and gab the metric in M. We use the following conformal transformation:
g̃μν = e2ζ (x)gμν (x), (1) with e2ξ (x) being a smooth function of the coordinates. Therefore, the expression e2ξ (x) is the conformal factor. By this transformation, angles are kept and distances between two points prescribed by the same coordinate are alerted. The transformation (1) becomes trivial when ζ (x) = const. Any theory that respects the transformation given by Eq. (1) is called a conformal field theory in which the nature of physics has a scale invariance.
There are two explanations for the transformation (1). One is for a constant background metric and the other is for a dynamical metric. For a constant metric, the transformation can be regarded as a physical symmetry of a dynamical system. On the other hand, for a dynamical metric, the transformation has a diffeomorphism; in other words, a gauge symmetry appears. For a review of the topic of conformal field theory one can refer to Refs. [58–61]. Recently, there have been many papers including the study of conformal transformations [62–67], in the area of cosmology [68,69], in higher-order curvature terms [70], and in quantum gravity [71]. Our main purpose is to find a novel spherically symmetric interior solution in a conformal TEGR theory and study its relevant physics.
The organization of this paper is as follows. In Sect. 2, we explain the conformal TEGR theory including mathematical definitions of tensors and field equations of gravitation. In Sect. 3, the field equations are applied to a 4D spherically symmetric vierbein field with non-diagonal components. We study the system of differential equations with specific forms of the unknowns of the ansate and the anisotropic function and succeed in deriving the remaining unknowns with three constants in Sect. 3. In Sect. 4, we present the necessary conditions that must be satisfied by real compact stellar objects. In Sect. 5 we show that the model under consideration

is non-singular in the center of a star and derive the gradient of its energy–momentum components as well as its speed of sound. In Sect. 6 we apply the junction conditions and derive the form of the constants in terms of the physical quantities numerically for the stellar object 4U 1608−52, with approximate radius R = 9.52 ± 0.15 km and mass M = 1.74 ± 0.14 M . Moreover, in Sect. 6 we show that the model bypasses a real compact stellar object graphically. In Sect. 7 we show that our model is stable using different methods: the Tolman–Oppenheimer– Volkoff (TOV) equation, the adiabatic index, and the static state. Also in Sect. 6, we show the consistency of our model with other pulsars. The final section is devoted to a discussion of the astrophysical consequences.

4. Necessary conditions of a realistic star The necessary conditions that a realistic star must satisfy are summarized as follows.
The metric potentials a(r) and b(r) and the matter components ρ(r), pr(r), pt(r) have finite values in the center of a star and are regular and free from singularity. The matter density ρ should be positive in all regions of a star, 0 ≤ ρ(r). Moreover, the value of ρ should be positive in the center and finite and should decrease across the boundary of the interior of a star, namely, 0 ≥ ρ ′(r) = dρdr . The radial pressure pr as well as the tangential one pt should be positive within a star, pr ≥ 0, pt ≥ 0. Moreover, the derivative of the pressure has to be negative within a star, d prdr < 0, d pt dr < 0. In the center of a star, the anisotropy vanishes, namely, (r → 0) = 0. The requirement of the energy conditions is necessary for an anisotropic fluid sphere. These conditions are described by the following forms, which are satisfied in all points of a star:
4The numerical values of the constants a0, a1, and c1 that will be fixed from the junction condition in Sect. 4 using the pulsar 4U 1608−52, whose approximate radius R = 9.52 ± 0.15 km and mass M = 1.74 ± 0.14 M , are used in Eq. (26).

(i) The dominant energy conditions (DEC): ρ ≥ |pr| and ρ ≥ |pt|. (ii) The strong energy condition (SEC): pr + ρ > 0, pt + ρ > 0, ρ − pr − 2pt > 0. (iii) The weak energy condition (WEC): pr + ρ > 0, ρ > 0. (iv) The null energy condition (NEC): pt + ρ > 0, ρ > 0.
The causality condition for a realistic star, i.e., the sound speed must be smaller than unity (in relativistic units of c = G = 1) in the interior of the star, i.e., 1 ≥ d ptdρ ≥ 0 and 1 ≥ d prdρ ≥ 0. The interior solution has to match the exterior Schwarzschild one in the star surface for ξ = 1 [64,67]. The adiabatic index has to be larger than 43 to have a stable model. For the stability analysis of an anisotropic star, it has been suggested [77] that the relation 0 <
vt2 − vr2 < 1 must be met. Here, vt and vr are the transverse and radial speeds, respectively. By using the physical conditions, we study whether the present model can satisfy the relations
mentioned above.
5. The physical conditions of the present model We examine Eq. (25) and confirm that it is appropriate for a realistic star.

Comparison of theoretical model with the observations of real stars Now, we convert back to the standard physical units to accurately determine the values of the model parameters under consideration numerically. Through the use of the masses and the radii of observed pulsars with the physical conditions that we referred to above, one can fix the constant parameters a0 and a1 and check their viability. Now, we employ the observational limits of the pulsar 4U 1608−52, with mass M = 1.74 ± 0.14M and R = 9.52 ± 0.15 km, where M( = 1.989 × 1030 kg) denotes the solar mass. Then, the boundary conditions given by Eq. (33) are able to fix the dimensionless constants.
We adopt the conditions listed previously to compare the present model to observational data. We study the pulsar 4U 1608−52 whose mass and radius are M = 1.74 ± 0.14M and R = 9.52 ± 0.15 km, respectively [79], and therefore we take M = 1.78M and R = 9.67km. We use the boundary conditions to examine the values of the constants a0 = −0.005 826 829 242, a1 = −0.089 720 785 94, and c1 = −0.029 523 446 94. With these constants, we depict physical quantities. We examine whether the present model can fit the observational data of realistic stars.
Figure 1(a) shows the metric potentials for 4U 1608−52. From this figure, we see that a(r → 0) = −0.089 720 785 94 and b(r → 0) = 1, both of which are finite in the center of a star.
Figures 1(b)–(d) plot the density and radial and tangential pressures, respectively. We see that the density and radial and tangential pressures are positive; they are large in the center and become smaller as the radii becomes larger. These behaviors are consistent with realistic stars. From Fig. 2(a), we understand that the spacetime becomes isotropic in the center of a star and the anisotropy is smaller at the surface of a star. Specifically, we find the negative anisotropic force r ; i.e., t is attractive due to the fact that pt − pr < 0. 8. Discussions and conclusions The TEGR theory is known to be identical to general relativity [91–93]. However, conformal TEGR is not equivalent to the conformal GR theory. In this research, we studied conformal TEGR field equations. In the present paper, we have explored the role of the conformal field on anisotropic compact objects by applying the field equations of conformal TEGR theory to a non-diagonal vierbein field. For exterior solutions, the scalar torsion vanishes when the two unknown functions approach Minkowski spacetime, which ensures that the vierbein field with which we begin is a physical one. The output differential equations consist of five non-linear ones in eight unknowns, a(r), b(r), ρ(r), pr(r), pt(r), V(r), ξ (r), and (r).
As a result, we have obtained an analytic solution for realistic compact star configurations. It has been demonstrated that the model proposed in this work is regular at the center as well as at the surface according to the stellar structure. In particular, the properties of the density
14/23
D ow nloaded from https://academ ic.oup.com /ptep/article/2022/10/103E01/6692964 by Indian Institute of Technology Patna user on 18 January 2024
as well as the radial and tangential pressures are regular for the case of a pulsar 4U 1608−52 [94].
Moreover, we have shown that the anisotropy and anisotropic forces have negative values that can be considered as attractive forces. This result originates from the fact that the radial pressure is stronger than the tangential pressure, i.e., pr > pt [95]. The present model is stable owing to the balance of the hydrostatic, gravitational, anisotropic, and scalar forces. In addition, with the procedures of the adiabatic index for a static state, the model is also shown to be stable. Furthermore, we have evaluated the sound speed and confirmed that it is consistent with the observations. According to this result, the metric potentials (21) and the anisotropy expression (24) are considered to be realistic for astrophysical compact objects. In addition, we have analyzed the present model by using observational data for pulsars (Tables 1 and 2) and shown that the present theoretical model can fit the observational data well.
The consequences obtained in this work are summarized as follows. We have employed a nondiagonal vierbein field yielding the vanishing torsion scalar as the metric potentials are close to unity. Such a behavior is important for the vierbein field as shown in Refs. [96–102]. It has also been demonstrated that the theoretical predictions of the present model are compatible with real observational data for pulsars. It is expected that the present study will be able to be tested for a wide range of metrics and anisotropies.
